title: [V2] Find out if you can get a DBS check for someone working for you

body.content:
Use this tool to find out if you can get a Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check for a job you’re recruiting for.

You can only check someone's criminal record if they work for you (or are applying to work for you) in certain roles. 

^This tool only covers roles in England and Wales. Find out if you can get a check in [Scotland](https://www.disclosurescotland.co.uk/disclosureinformation/index.htm) or [Northern Ireland](http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/accessni-checks).^ 

##Managers
Managers are eligible for the same check as the staff they’re managing. If you’re checking for a manager, check the eligibility of their staff. 

##Roles that aren't covered
This tool doesn't cover:  

+ roles in the armed forces 
+ adoption or fostering


##If you're applying for a job
You can’t get a check for yourself but you can use this tool to see if your employer can check your criminal record.

If your employer can’t check your record they may ask you to [request a basic disclosure](http://www.disclosurescotland.co.uk/basicdisclosureonline/index.htm) instead.

*[DBS]: Disclosure and Barring Service
*[CRB]: Criminal Record Bureau

nodes.title: What kind of role is the check for?

options.label: Working with adults receiving health or social care

nodes.title: What does the work with children involve?

options.label: Childminding (includes people living on childminding premises)
Working in a school, nursery, children's centre or home, detention service or childcare premises
Helping ill or disabled children with eating, drinking, washing, dressing or going to the toilet
Giving advice about physical, emotional or educational wellbeing, eg as a therapist
Working in a children's hospital in a non-medical role, eg cleaner
Moderating an online chatroom or online media

nodes.title: Will the work be carried out frequently?

body.content:
Answer 'yes' if the role involves any of the following:

+ working once a week or more with children 
+ working four times a month or more with children 
+ ever working overnight (between 2am and 6am) where there may be face-to-face contact with children

Answer ‘yes’ if the role involves any of the following:

  • working once a week or more with children
  • working four times a month or more with children
  • ever working overnight (between 2am and 6am) where there may be face-to-face contact with children

Teaching, advising or guiding them, eg giving therapy
Working in a care home, but not in a caring role, eg as a cleaner

body.content:
Being a childminder is [regulated activity](/government/publications/dbs-check-eligible-positions-guidance), which means people barred from working with children can't do this role. 

For childminders you can get: 

+ an [enhanced check](/disclosure-barring-service-check) 
+ a [children’s barred list check](/disclosure-barring-service-check/dbs-barred-lists) 

##People who live or work with the childminder
You can also request these checks for anyone 16 or over who lives or works on childminding premises.
